channel.description: Recent content in fiction on Strat

item.title: Brave New World
item.description: Brave New World is a dystopian novel from 1932 about dystopian shit and it has a lot to say about the dystopia we’re currently living in.

item.title: Terraform: Watch/Worlds/Burn
item.description: A collection of science-fiction short stories that’ll make you go “huh, interesting…” and might encourage you to think about how technology affects your life currently and how it might affect it in the not so distant future.

item.title: Good Omens
item.description: A cool guy devil and a flamboyantly effeminate angel living on Earth try to stop the end times from happening because they’ve come to enjoy all of Earth’s pleasures (mosly driving fast cars and reading, respectively). Also, there’s the anti-christ, a descendant of a prophet who’s predicted everything, some dude, etc. There’s a lot going on here.

item.title: The Colour of Magic
item.description: An incompetent wizard is tasked with protecting a visitor visiting from a faraway land. A fantasy novel for people who don’t like fantasy novels.

item.title: Truth of the Divine
item.description: Aliens on Earth in the early/mid 2000s and everything that follows from that. Sequel to Axiom’s End, continues Cora’s story and adds some new fresh characters (alien and otherwise) into the mix.

item.title: Axiom's End
item.description: Set in 2007, the novel is about a U.S. government coverup of contact with extraterrestrial life. You follow the story of Cora, daughter of an exiled whistleblower, who finds herself in the middle of the whole ‘alien’ situation.

item.title: Living Beyond Borders: Growing up Mexican in America
item.description: An anthology of short stories, comics, and poems from Mexican American authors.

item.title: The Odyssey
item.description: The Odyssey is a classic and there’s more stories that have been inspired by it than I can count. After reading it, you’ll be able to see it echoed everywhere you look.

item.title: Norse Mythology
item.description: Neil Gaiman’s Norse Mythology is a retelling of a few stories from Norse mythology (which we don’t know very much about). I’m a fan of Neil Gaiman’s work generally but I found this to be quite boring.

item.title: Sandcastles
item.description: Sandcastles is the french comic book that the recent M. Night Shyamalan’s movie Old was based on. A bunch of different people arrive for a relaxing day at the beach and find themselves aging extremely rapidly, babies become teens and older folk die. Hijinks ensue. I don’t get it.

item.title: Remina
item.description: Junji Ito is cool. Uzumaki is great. A lot of his other work is just OK. I think Remina is also just OK.

item.title: The Drifting Classroom
item.description: The Drifting Classroom is a Japanese horror manga series published from 1972 to 1974 that follows a school (and its students) that is mysteriously transported through time to a post-apocalyptic future.
